headline.main: Cost of Substance Abuse Put at $20 Billion

keywords.value: CENTER FOR ADDICTION AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: One of every five dollars New Yorkers pay in city taxes is spent coping with the effects of smoking, drinking and drug use, according to a study released yesterday by the Center for Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University. The study calculated that substance abuse cost New York City $20 billion in 1994, the year analyzed. Much of that expense was borne by the Federal and state governments through programs like Medicaid, and by private business, through higher security costs and lost productivity. The city's share amounted to $3.8 billion of the $18 billion it collected in taxes, or 21 cents of every city tax dollar.
